1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
We at Allied Agronomy, LLC are strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is an inherent part of our comprehensive Accidental Release Prevention Program that covers areas such as (but, not limited to)design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training, all associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement the appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. We also coordinate our response efforts with the local Fire Department, Law Enforcement, and Emergency Medical Services, all which provide additional emergency response information and expertise.

 2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:
 Our facility's primary activities include support services for agricultural crop production.  We have anhydrous ammonia stored at our facility, in both a primary holding tank(s), as well as supplemental nurse tanks, which are used for product field application.  All of our tanks are filled by skilled, trained employees who do not fill any tank beyond the 85% standard maximum storage capacity.

 4. General Accidental Release Prevention Program :
Our facility has taken the necessary steps to comply with the EPA's accidental release prevention requirements as set forth in 40 CFR part 68.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source:

Process Safety Information:
Allied Agronomy, LLC maintains a currant and detailed data base of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with all processes (Appendix

E).

Process Hazard Analysis:
Our facility conducts routine, comprehensive studies to ensure all hazards that maybe associated with our processes are identified and controlled effectively.  Any findings from the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures:
Allied Agronomy, LLC maintains strict written operating procedures to ensure that activities within our covered processes are conducted safely.  These procedures address various modes of operation; the information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to all operators involved in the processes (Appendix B).

Training:
Allied Agronomy, LLC has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that all employees who are involved with operating processes and procedures are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.

Mechanical Integrity:
Allied Agronomy, LLC conducts regular, documented maintenance checks on all process equipment to ensure safe, proper operation.  Maintenance checks are conducted by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Examples of process equipment that would receive maintenance checks include:  pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are taken out of service and corrected in a safe and timely manner (Appendix C).

Management of Change:
Written procedures are in place at Allied Agronomy, LLC to manage changes in process
chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel and/or other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly notified of the modification and receive updated training to deal with it.

Pre-startup Reviews:
Allied Agronomy, LLC routinely conducts pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and modifications in established processes.  These review

s are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits:
Allied Agronomy, LLC conducts compliance audits on a regular basis to determine whether the plan's provisions, set out under the 40 CFR part 68, are being implemented.  Any non-compliance issue discovered during the audit is promptly noted and immediately corrected.

Employee Participation:
Allied Agronomy, LLC truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP, particularly information resulting from process hazard analyses.

  5. Five-year Accident History:
Allied Agronomy, LLC has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, no accidental release has occurred during this period.

  6. Emergency Response Plan:
Allied Agronomy, LLC maintains a written Emergency Action Plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan addresses all aspects of emergency response including first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, and, in the event of an accidental release, Allied Agronomy, LLC will contact local emergency response agencies and the public (Appendix A).  Allied Agronomy, LLC maintains a written Emergency Action Plan which is coordinated with the local Fire Department and the county's Emergency Manager.  The plan is intended to assist responding agencies to address all aspects of emergency response including first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, and notification of other local emergency response agencies and the public.  The Fire Department conducts regular, routine training ses

sions at this location assisted by our facility personnel.

  7.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
Allied Agronomy, LLC will continue to provide our employees with currant and ongoing annual training (and more frequently, if necessary) to ensure that they are up-to-date with all of the safe anhydrous ammonia transfer and handling procedures, all Federal, State, Regional, and Local regulations that may apply, as well as provide regular inspection and maintenance on all of the ammonia equipment.  Only authorized personnel (authorized by management) will make changes to the facility if any audits of the facility identify non-compliance with Section 112 (r)(7), Accidental Release Prevention Requirements of the Clean Air Act.
